summary.p: Single parchment folio, Shelfmark: sxm/ag. 2529; Qurʾānic Text: Q 4:127-135; Lines per page: 13; Dimensions: 345 x 240 mm; Script style: kūfī, variation of the type D.Va; Estimated date of production: 750-850.

Originally sxm/ag. 2529 is probably from the same codex as HC.MS.03168 and HC.MS.03113 (Qatar National Library, Doha), AL-15 (Library of Congress, Washington) as well as one folio in the Lausanne Collection.

The catalogue of the Oriental collection of the Georgian Nationalmuseum has the following information about this fragment (Oriental Collections of the Georgian National Museum, Irina Koshoridze (ed.), Tbilisi 2012, p. 59): "A fragment of a Qur'anic manuscript. Abbasid Caliphate. VIII-IX centuries. Parchment, ink, gold. 34.5 x 24 cm. Sxm/ag. 2529 presents one of the earliest pages of the Qurʾān. Sura 4 of the Qurʾān ("Women"), is written on parchment in a horizontal format in thirteen lines, which is typical of early examples. The kūfī calligraphic style of the Arabic script, diacritical marks - red dots and gold colored dividing rosettes are used." "ყურანის ხელნაწერის ფრაგმენტი. აბასიანთა სახალიფო. VIII-IX სს. პერგამენტი, მელანი, ოქრო. 34,5 x 24 სმ. სხმ/აღ. 2529 წარმოდგენილია ერთ-ერთი ადრეული ყურანის ფურცელი. ყურანის მე-4 სურა („ქალები“), შერსულებულია ჰორიზონტალური ფორმატის პერგამენტზე ცამეტ სტრიქონად, რაც ძირითადად ადრეული ნიმუშებისთვისაა დამახასიათებელი. გამოყენებულია არაბული დამწერლობის ქუფური კალიგრაფიული სტილი, დიაკრიტიკული ნიშნები - წითელი წერტილები და ოქროთი დაფერილი გამყოფი როზეტები."

support.p: Recto is flesh side, verso is hair side. The text on the verso is better preserved than on the recto side. The structure of the quire is not known.

Division of the text: There are single, fifth and tenth verse separators. Single verse separators consist of small gold rosettes. The tenth verse separator preserved on the verso side of the folio is a larger gold painted medallion, representing the end of verse number 130. Inside the ornament, miʾa wa ṯalāṯūn (arabic: "130") is written. Red, green, yellow and blue pigments are used for the medallion. It should be noted that according to the Cairo edition the taʿšīr marker is placed after the 131st verse.

summary.p: The script of this Qurʾān fragment represents the kūfī script style D being close to the D.Va group with elements of D.I/D.II as these subgroups are very similar (Déroche 1983: PN 112-116), (Déroche 1992: PN 44-45). The letter ʾalif in the independent form has a long lower return with an upward curve. The letter ǧīm in the medial form lies on the base line so that the letter before it is placed a little bit higher. In the final or independent position ǧīm has a tail that curves back to the head of the letter close to the line, similar to the D.I/D.II group. The letter ṭāʾ in the final or independent position is similar to those in the D.Va group. ʿAyn initially resembles the D.Va group. In middle position, the letter shows a vertical right hand antenna which remains vertical in final position as well. Qāf in its final or independent form shows a U-shaped tail that goes backwards as in D.II group. The letter mīm in middle and final position is closer to D.II and D.III group. In both positions the letter lies rather flat on the line, in final position it has a short flat tail. Nūn in final and independent position has a long body and the head is shorter than in D.I, being closer to D.III. Hāʾ in the medial position is placed on the base line, the two eyes are mostly defined. The shape of the letter, which resembles a drop is close to the D.Va group. The lām-ʾalif ligature also resembles D.Va and D.I group, but the lām is much thinner than ʾalif and curves towards it.
Unlike Déroche, we use the term kūfī for pragmatic reasons - a term which is attested only after the 10th century.

Diacritics: Diacritica of the script are marked by oblique dashes in the same dark brown ink as the main text, mostly, the letters bāʾ and nūn in final or independent position are marked. Vocalisation is indicated by red and green dots. Some lines show mašq, horizontal stretching of the letters, a technique used to achieve a regular arrangement of letters within a line.
